thread.title: Bears vs. Chiefs: The matchups
thread.title_full: Bears vs. Chiefs: The matchups - Chicago Tribune

author: Rich Campbell
title: Bears vs. Chiefs: The matchups
text:
Bears on offense
IN THE AIR
NFL ranks: Bears offense 29th, Chiefs defense 28th
Quarterback Jay Cutler was mobile enough in the pocket against the Raiders to extend plays. That should improve now that he's another week removed from the strained hamstring he suffered Sept. 20. The Bears are once again depleted at receiver, though, with Alshon Jeffery (hamstring) facing his fourth straight absence and Eddie Royal (ankle) missing practice time. Cornerback Sean Smith returned from suspension last Sunday to lift the Chiefs' maligned secondary. First-round rookie cornerback Marcus Peters moves fluidly and contests throws.
ON THE GROUND
Bears offense 11th, Chiefs defense 14th
The Bears offensive-line depth will be tested by a powerful Chiefs front. The center position is in flux because of Will Montgomery's season-ending broken left leg. Third-round rookie Hroniss Grasu struggled to consistently anchor in the preseason, but he has added more than 10 pounds and feels capable of controlling defensive linemen. Charles Leno will start at left tackle because Jermon Bushrod (concussion/shoulder) is still out. Chiefs nose tackle Jaye Howard is having a breakout season, using good hand technique and power to disrupt opponents' running games.
Bears 26th in total offense, 28th in points scored
Chiefs 29th in total defense, T-31st in points allowed
Bears on defense
IN THE AIR
NFL ranks: Chiefs offense 13th , Bears defense 4th
Quarterback Alex Smith has been sacked 19 times, most in the NFL. Right tackle Eric Fisher, the No. 1 pick in 2013, has been inconsistent with his technique. The Bears must respect receiver Jeremy Maclin's speed, but no other Chiefs receiver has more than six catches. Tight end Travis Kelce is a rugged runner after the catch. Bears lineman Jarvis Jenkins has earned playing time on third down because of his high motor and strong hands rushing the passer.
ON THE GROUND
Chiefs offense 15th , Bears defense 24th
The Chiefs offense runs through Jamaal Charles, whose agility and speed make him one of the best running backs in the league. "Even for a smaller guy, he still plays with good power and strength," Bears coach John Fox said. Nose tackle Jeremiah Ratliff (left ankle) expects to make his season debut. He brings toughness and savvy to a line that limited Raiders running backs to a 3.4-yard average last Sunday. The Bears will be inexperienced at safety no matter who starts in place of Antrel Rolle (right ankle).
Chiefs 14th in total offense, 10th in points scored
Bears 7th in total defense, T-31st in points allowed
